confession.seduction_context: when she was in despair over husband's gambling - he would play until 2 at night, but was otherwise a good man
sabbat_activities: plotted to make hail or damage woods

testimony.quarrel_subject: Her husband with 2 or 3 others had beaten husband of witness, while accused encouraged them rather than restraining them
angry because they used another blacksmith at Amenoncourt
quarrel on way to market at Blamont before previous Christmas
killed one of her geese with a stone
testimony.threat_quote: he would pay more dearly than at the market

testimony.quarrel_subject: claiming he had charged her too much tax
daughter passed Jennon washing and did not offer to help her
testimony.threat_quote: Before last Christmas had told Alizon she would give something to her god-daughter (one of her daughters) so that she should never have any more children
he would repent for calling her a witch

testimony.quarrel_subject: her husband (presumably Demenge Aulbry) killed goose
passed Jennon washing and did not offer to help her
testimony.threat_quote: Jennon had told her she would not have any more children

testimony.quarrel_subject: she had been angry with him, accusing him of causing her husband to spend money on drink and go dancing at fête

testimony.threat_quote: she wished they might have as many devils as they asked for gros, with other threats

testimony.quarrel_subject: Found a chest had been burgled, and suspected Jennon

testimony.threat_quote: she wished they might have as many devils as they asked for gros

testimony.quarrel_subject: her husband, as bannard, had Jennon fined for taking wild pears. Later they saw witness collecting wood and said she should be fined like others
testimony.threat_quote: he would have her or the devil would

economic_context.details: Multiple disputes over tax collection, fines for taking wild pears and wild plums, concern over gambling debts of husband. Accused was pregnant and desired fresh meat, suggesting possible food scarcity. Sibile Tabourin worked as diviner 'to earn a little bread, in view of her poverty.'

harms_catalog.harm_description: beaten, had to spend 2 or 3 days in bed
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Her husband with 2 or 3 others beat him while she encouraged them
angry because they used another blacksmith at Amenoncourt

harms_catalog.harm_description: found lying in snow, recovered, then became mortally ill 2 weeks later and died
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: quarrel on way to market at Blamont before previous Christmas
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: a week later found in snow, died about 3 weeks after quarrel
harms_catalog.method_alleged: witchcraft - he claimed she was responsible and saw her by his bed

harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: killed one of her geese with a stone
threatened her husband, claiming he had charged her too much tax

harms_catalog.harm_description: miscarriage at 5 months pregnant, so ill she received sacraments; later sudden illness again after accused visited; suspected loss of ability to have more children
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: daughter passed Jennon washing and did not offer to help; whirlwind incident
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: immediately after whirlwind; 3 days after miscarriage
harms_catalog.method_alleged: witchcraft via whirlwind, visits, and giving apples and pears
gave piece of tart to niece

harms_catalog.harm_description: sickened and died with unknown illness
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: she threatened him during tax collection, wishing they might have as many devils as they asked for gros
Found chest had been burgled, suspected Jennon; she heard of this

harms_catalog.method_alleged: made a sign of the cross on her stomach with a knife she was holding

harms_catalog.harm_description: fell ill, was in bed for 6 weeks

harms_catalog.method_alleged: witchcraft after threat from husband and Jennon

harms_catalog.method_alleged: yellow powder - said they were small orphans and she had trouble looking after them

legal_context.redress_outcome: Claimed that when she went to ask Bastien Charpentier if he had called her witch, he denied this in presence of curé
legal_context.imprisonment_conditions: Asked to see greffier in prison to write to holy father at Nancy

hearsay_chains.content: 8 years earlier when arrested, Jehenne Mercier told them that Claude Bastien suspected her of causing his illness, but it was Jennon who had done it
Story about accusation by Jehenne Mercier
suspicions of Jean Batho about accused
Story of her husband killing goose, followed by threat and death of horse
whirlwind incident and accused's visits with fruit
Story of threats against Demenge Bagrat over tax collection, and death of horse
Knew some from Gondrexon had told accused of niece's death

emotional_state_notes: asked to see greffier in prison to write to holy father at Nancy to determine if she was a witch
said she had no doubt she was not a witch
during torture warned they should not press her further or she might accuse worthy people
after death sentence was read, discharged those she accused, saying she had done so falsely

reproaches_to_witnesses.objection: Said that Jennon veuve Jean Batho was 'une variable, mauvaise sotte, et mauvaise langue' (a changeable, wicked fool, and wicked tongue)

Said that Sibile veuve Germain Tabourin was a woman 'qui va au devin pour les uns et les autres' (who goes to the diviner for one and the other). Latter replied that accused herself had sent her in case of her husband, and that she went for others to earn a little bread, in view of her poverty
Said his horse died because he made it pull a heavy load of wood, not because of her curse
Agreed to quarrel with Demenge Bagrat over tax, but not to threats
Had said to midwife 'que portant quelque chose aux malades, elle en recevoit des mauvais fames' (that bringing something to the sick, she received bad reputations from it)
Claimed that when she went to ask Bastien Charpentier if he had called her witch, he denied this in presence of curé
Accused claimed she was not driven away, but offered a plate of cooked peas (witness denied this, saying they had none at the time)

extraction_metadata.notes: Trial of Jeannon Marchal from Autrepierre. Strong pattern of quarrels over economic matters (tax, fines, property) followed by death of horses and people. Husband had gambling problem which was cited as reason for her despair when seduced by devil. Confessed under torture but retracted accusations after death sentence was read. 22 witnesses testified with general reputation and specific harm allegations. Multiple animal deaths (primarily horses) and human deaths/illnesses. Tortured with thumbscrews and rack. Executed.
